overview: The subject offers a range of projects in modules that offer experience in laboratory techniques and computational methods; the relative weights are indicated in the module descriptions. Students must select four projects with a combined weighting that contains at least 25% Computational Physics and 25% Laboratory Physics. The laboratory projects include nuclear physics, particle physics, diffraction, electronics, atomic physics, optical physics and astronomy. The computational projects are designed to develop programming skills and to introduce a range of numerical methods commonly used in physics research will be based on model problems in physics; these may include electronic structure theory, molecular vibrations, stellar structure, quantum spin systems, large-scale magnetic systems and gravitational lensing by point masses. Some projects may be offered that merge laboratory and computational work with approximately equal weighting.
intended learning outcomes: demonstrate an understanding of a wide variety of advanced experimental and data analysis techniques;
acquire, analyse and interpret experimental data; and
write and evaluate scientific and technical reports.

explain the application of a variety of computational techniques including differencing, root finding, quadrature, ordinary and partial differential equations, matrix eigenvalue problems, Monte Carlo methods, fast Fourier transforms and data processing algorithms to physical problems; and
apply these methods to a range of physical situations and to experimental data.

assessments.description: Four reports (one on each of the four projects to be undertaken in the subject) equivalent to 800 words each. Project report due dates distributed through the teaching period of the Semester. 4x15% (each report). 3200 words (total)
One report drafted as a scientific journal article. 800 words (equivalent)
Record keeping of laboratory work and documentation of computer programs. Assessed at the completion of each project
Participation in Laboratory and Computational classes. Continuously assessed during contact hours
Hurdle requirement:. Attendance of not less than 80% of allocated laboratory and computational classes

Semester 1.Contact hours: 3 x three hour laboratory or computational classes per week for eight weeks during the semester

Semester 2.Contact hours: 3 x three hour laboratory or computational classes per week for eight weeks during the semester

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
